environmental_biodegradations.References: (1) ECHA; Search for Chemicals. Chromium Triacetate (CAS 1066-30-4) Registered Substances Dossier. European Chemical Agency. Available from, as of Oct 20, 2015: https://echa.europa.eu/
environmental_biodegradations.Value: Using OECD Guideline 301A (new version) (Ready Biodegradability: DOC Die Away Test) with an adapted activated sludge inoculum, chromium (III) acetate (at 40 mg/L) was found to be readily biodegradable with 33.8, 84.5, 89.3 and 91.8% degradation after 1, 3 ,7 and 9 days of incubation, respectively(1).

logP.References: ECHA; Search for Chemicals. Chromium Triacetate (CAS 1066-30-4) Registered Substances Dossier. European Chemical Agency. Available from, as of Oct 20, 2015: https://echa.europa.eu/
logP.Value: log Kow = 0.2 at 22 °C, pH 5 (OECD Guideline 117 (Partition Coefficient (n-octanol / water), HPLC Method))

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Chronic Exposure or Carcinogenicity/ ... No tumors occurred after 2 yr at site of 8 intrapleural implantations over 13 MO of 25 mg chromic(iii) acetate in gelatin capsules to 42 rats.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Chronic Exposure or Carcinogenicity/ Groups of 54 male and 54 female swiss mice that received 5 mg/L chromic(III) acetate in drinking water for life developed no more tumors than did control mice. No difference was found in the survival of females compared with controls, but treated males died 100 days earlier than control males (831 versus 957 days); only 60% of the males survived 18 months. ... Chromic(III) acetate was given in drinking water at ... 5 mg/L to 46 male & 50 female long evans rats for lifespan ... /did not significantly/ incr ... incidence of tumors at various sites ... of either sex as compared with controls. ... Tumor-bearing ... were: 16/39 treated males, 18/35 treated females; 9/35 male controls and 15/35 female controls ... .

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Chronic Exposure or Carcinogenicity/ In groups of 22-34 rats that received im implantations of various chromium compounds, the following incidences of implantation-site tumors (type unspecified) ... observed after 27 mo: calcium chromate(VI), 9/32 (22 alive at 1 yr), ... sodium dichromate(VI), 0/33 (25 alive at 1 yr), ... chromic(III) acetate, 1/34 (30 alive at 1 yr); and sintered calcium chromate(VI), 12/34 (22 alive at 1 yr). None of 32 control rats given implants of sheep fat alone developed local tumors (30 alive at 1 yr).

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /GENOTOXICITY/ ... Chromic(III) acetate ... /was/ inactive /inducing forward mutation/ at ... 200 times the maximum dose at which cell survival was measurable after treatment with potassium dichromate(VI) /in Chinese hamster V79 /cells/.

/GENOTOXICITY/ The recently developed strain TA102, particularly suited to the detection of oxidative mutagens, was the most sensitive out of 9 strains of S. typhimurium his- in revealing the mutagenicity of Cr(VI) compounds (sodium dichromate, calcium chromate and chromium trioxide). The rank of sensitivity was the following: TA102, TA100, TA97, TA92, TA1978, TA98, TA1538 and TA1537, TA1535 being the only insensitive strain. Cr(III) compounds (chromic acetate, chromic nitrate and chromic potassium sulfate) were totally inactive with all strains. The direct mutagenicity of Cr(VI) was markedly decreased, through NADPH-requiring mechanisms, by rat-liver S9 fractions and, to a lower extent, by human lung S12 fractions, which supports the hypothesis of a metabolically regulated threshold in chromium pulmonary carcinogenicity.

soil_absorption_mobility.References: (1) ECHA; Search for Chemicals. Chromium Triacetate (CAS 1066-30-4) Registered Substances Dossier. European Chemical Agency. Available from, as of Oct 20, 2015: https://echa.europa.eu/ (2) Swann RL et al; Res Rev 85: 17-28 (1983)
soil_absorption_mobility.Value: Using OECD Guideline 121 (Estimation of the Adsorption Coefficient (Koc) on Soil and on Sewage Sludge using High Performance Liquid Chromatography (HPLC)), chromium (III) acetate was estimated to have a log Koc of <1.5 (Koc of 31.6)(1). According to a classification scheme(2), this estimated Koc value suggests that chromium (III) acetate is expected to have very high mobility in soil.

soil_absorption_mobility.References: (1) ECHA; Search for Chemicals. Chromium Triacetate (CAS 1066-30-4) Registered Substances Dossier. European Chemical Agency. Available from, as of Oct 20, 2015: https://echa.europa.eu/
soil_absorption_mobility.Value: Chromium (VI) anions can be considered to be mobile in sediments in the environment, except possibly under highly acidic conditions(1). In contrast chromium (III), the oxidation state in which chromium is present in acetic acid, chromium salt, appears to be much more strongly adsorbed to soils and sediments than chromium (VI)(1). The adsorption of chromium (III) onto soil follows the pattern typical of cationic metals and increases with increasing pH (lowering pH results in increased protonation of the adsorbent leading to fewer adsorption sites for the cationic metal) and the organic matter content of the soil and decreases when other competing (metal) cations are present(1). Certain dissolved organic ligands may also reduce the adsorption of chromium (III) to the solid phase by forming complexes which enhance the solubility of chromium (III) in the aqueous phase(1).
